result_equations.equation: V_H = (I B)/(n q t) = R_H (I B)/t

explanation: The Hall effect occurs when a current-carrying conductor is placed in a magnetic field perpendicular to the current direction, resulting in a voltage difference across the conductor. This effect allows determination of charge carrier density, mobility, and type (positive or negative) in materials, making it fundamental for semiconductor characterization and magnetic field sensing.

equations_assumptions.text: The magnetic field is uniform and perpendicular to the current direction.
The conductor has a single type of charge carrier with well-defined mobility.

derivation.equation: vec F_magnetic = q vec v times vec B
At equilibrium: vec F_magnetic + vec F_electric = 0
q v B = q E_H => E_H = v B
V_H = E_H * w = v B w
I = n q v A = n q v w t
V_H = (I B w)/(n q w t) = (I B)/(n q t)

derivation_assumptions.text: Equilibrium is reached between magnetic and electric forces on charge carriers.
The conductor geometry is well-defined with uniform current distribution.

derivation_explanation.text: Moving charges in a magnetic field experience a Lorentz force perpendicular to both velocity and field.
Charge accumulation creates an electric field that exerts a force on the carriers.
At steady state, the magnetic and electric forces balance each other.
Solve for the Hall electric field from the force balance condition.
The Hall voltage is the electric field times the width of the conductor.
Express current in terms of carrier density, charge, velocity, and cross-sectional area.
Solve for the drift velocity in terms of current and material parameters.
Substitute to get the Hall voltage in terms of measurable quantities.
